metadata.title: HTCC as a highly effective polymeric inhibitor of SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV 2 3

abstract.text: The beginning of 2020 brought us information about the novel coronavirus emerging in China. 39 Rapid research resulted in the characterization of the pathogen, which appeared to be a member 40 of the SARS-like cluster, commonly seen in bats. Despite the global and local efforts, the virus 41 escaped the healthcare measures and rapidly spread in China and later globally, officially 42 causing a pandemic and global crisis in March 2020. At present, different scenarios are being 43 written to contain the virus, but the development of novel anticoronavirals for all highly 44 pathogenic coronaviruses remains the major challenge. Here, we describe the antiviral activity 45 of previously developed by us HTCC compound (N-(2-hydroxypropyl)-3-trimethylammonium 46 chitosan chloride), which may be used as potential inhibitor of currently circulating highly 47 pathogenic coronaviruses -SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV. : bioRxiv preprint 65 pneumocytes in human airways, hijacking the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) to 66 enter the cell, similarly as SARS-CoV and HCoV-NL63. 67 MERS-CoV is related to SARS-CoV-2, but together with some bat viruses forms 68 a separate Merbecovirus subgenus. Bats are believed to serve as an original reservoir also in 69 this case 10 , but camels were identified as the intermediate host 11 . The virus never fully crossed 70 the species border, as the human-to-human transmission is limited, and almost all the cases are 71 associated with animal-to-human transmission. The entry receptor for MERS-CoV is the 72 dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) 12,13 . In humans, MERS-CoV causes a respiratory illness with 73 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

body_text.text: Coronaviruses mainly cause respiratory and enteric diseases in humans, other mammals, 50 and birds. However, some species can cause more severe conditions such as hepatitis, 51 peritonitis, or neurological disease. Seven coronaviruses infect humans, four of which (human pangolins were suggested as such 9 . The virus is associated with a respiratory illness that, in a 63 proportion of cases, is severe. The mortality rate varies between locations, but at present, is 64 estimated to reach 3-4% globally. The virus infects primarily ciliated cells and type II severity varying from asymptomatic to potentially fatal acute respiratory distress [14] [15] [16] . To date, 74 MERS-CoV infection was confirmed in 27 countries, with over 2,000 cases and a mortality rate 75 of ~35%. 76 Currently, there are no vaccines or drugs with proven efficacy to treat coronavirus 77 infection, and treatment is limited to supportive care. However, a range of therapeutics have Consequently, broad-spectrum antivirals are essential in long-term perspective. we dissected the mechanism of the HTCC antiviral activity. We showed that the polymer 96 interacts with the coronaviral Spike (S) protein and blocks its interaction with the cellular 97 receptor 22-24 . Here, we analyzed the HTCC activity against SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV in 98 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.29.014183 doi: bioRxiv preprint vitro using permissive cell lines and ex vivo, using a model of human airway epithelium (HAE). 99 The study showed that the replication of both viruses was efficiently hampered. Overall, our 100 data show that HTCC polymers are potent broad-spectrum anticoronavirals and may be very 101 promising drug candidates for SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV. 105 Previously, we showed that HTCC with different degrees of substitution (DSs) is a The study on the MERS-CoV using the Vero cells revealed that all HTCC variants 117 inhibit virus replication to a similar extent (~100-1000-time decrease in viral yields), at non-118 toxic concentration (Figure 1A, C) . The inhibition of the SARS-CoV-2 infection in Vero E6 119 cells was even more pronounced, and all HTCC variants inhibited virus replication by ~10,000 120 times at non-toxic concentration (Figure 1B, C) . In this case, the HTCC-63 was arbitrarily 121 selected for further studies on MERS-CoV, while HTCC-77 was selected for SARS-CoV-2. 122 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The inhibitory activity of selected 134 polymers was verified for three different concentrations, and obtained data are shown in Figure   135 2.
body_text.section: HTCCs hamper MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 replication in cell lines

body_text.text: Based on the data obtained, the basic parameters were calculated and are presented in Table 1 . The parameters observed for the SARS-CoV-2 appear to be favorable with SI above 12. It is 148 also worth to note that HTCC was previously administered by inhalation in rats, and no adverse 149 reactions were observed 25 . In that study, HTCC was used as a carrier for the active substance, 150 and as such, was reported to be promising for local sustained inhalation therapy of pulmonary 151 diseases.

This is especially important for compounds, which activity is based on electrostatic The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.29.014183 doi: bioRxiv preprint 182 Our previous research showed that the HTCC-mediated inhibition of coronaviral The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.29.014183 doi: bioRxiv preprint Next, to verify whether the mechanism of action for the highly pathogenic 219 betacoronaviruses is similar to that observed for alphacoronaviruses 22 , and is based on locking 220 the interaction between the virus and the entry receptor, we analyzed MERS-CoV The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.29.014183 doi: bioRxiv preprint

Taking together, we show here that the previously developed and described polymeric 239 HTCC anticoronaviral compounds based on chitosan are able to efficiently inhibit infection 240 with emerging coronaviruses. We believe that the HTCC can be fine-tuned to target any 241 coronavirus, and this interaction is specific to viruses that belong to the Coronaviridae family.

FIGREF0.text: 52 coronavirus [HCoV]-229E, HCoV-NL63, HCoV-OC43, and HCoV-HKU1) cause relatively 53 mild upper and lower respiratory tract disease. Other three zoonotic coronaviruses -the severe 54 acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses (SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2) and the Middle East 55 respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) are associated with severe, life-threatening 56 respiratory infections and multiorgan failure 1-7 . 57 SARS-CoV-2 emerged in the Hubei province of China by the end of 2019 and caused 58 an epidemic that was partially contained in China by March 2020. However, the virus rapidly 59 spread globally and caused the pandemic 8 . SARS-CoV-2 is a betacoronavirus and belongs to 60 a large cluster of SARS-like viruses in bats, classified in Sarbecovirus subgenus. While bats 61 are considered to be the original reservoir, it is believed that there is an intermediate host, and 62

FIGREF1.text: 78 been experimentally used in clinic to treat SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV-infected patients, and 79 their use is based on the knowledge obtained in previous years. The most promising drug 80 candidates include broad-spectrum polymerase inhibitors (remdesivir) 17 and some re-purposed 81 drugs (e.g., HIV-1 protease inhibitors). However, until today none of these has proven effective 82 in randomized controlled trials. On the other hand, the antiviral potential of several small 83 molecules have been demonstrated in cell lines in vitro, but their effectiveness in vivo have not 84 been confirmed 18,19 . For the ones that reached animal models, some promising drug candidates 85 have been shown to exacerbate the disease (ribavirin, mycophenolic acid) 20 . 86 Drug development for SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV is of great importance, but 87 considering the diversity of coronaviruses and the proven propensity to cross the species barrier, 88 the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic is probably not the last one. Warnings about the possibility of 89 another SARS-CoV epidemic have appeared in the scientific literature for a long time 21 .90

FIGREF2.text: Previously, we have demonstrated an antiviral potential of the HTCC polymer (N-(2-92 hydroxypropyl)-3-trimethylammonium chitosan chloride), which efficiently hampered 93 infection of all low pathogenic human coronaviruses in vitro and ex vivo 22 and several animal 94 coronaviruses (unpublished data). Furthermore, using several functional and structural assays,

FIGREF5.text: 106 potent inhibitor of all four low pathogenic HCoVs 22 . DSs are expressed as the fraction of NH2 107 groups of gluocosamine units in chitosan substituted with glycidyltrimethylammonium chloride 108 (GTMAC). The DS of the studied HTCC polymers varied between 57% and 77%; thus, the 109 polymers were named HTCC-57, HTCC-62, HTCC-63, HTCC-65, and HTCC-77. The 110 synthesis and characterization of polymers are described elsewhere 22,23 . The analysis showed 111 that HTCC-63 demonstrated the most significant inhibitory effect on HCoV-NL63, HCoV-112 OC43, and HCoV-HKU1. On the other hand, HTCC-62 and HTCC-77 proved to be effective 113 inhibitors of HCoV-229E infection. Further, HTCC-65 effectively inhibited the replication of 114 HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-OC43, while HTCC-62 showed a potent antiviral effect on HCoV-115 HKU1 infection.

FIGREF7.text: In vitro inhibition of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 by HTCC at non toxic concentration. Vero cells were 124 infected with MERS-CoV (A), and Vero E6 cells were infected with SARS-CoV-2 (B). Briefly, cultures were 125 inoculated with a given virus in the presence of HTCC (100 μg/ml) or control PBS. Replication of viruses was 126 evaluated at 48 h post-inoculation using RT-qPCR. The data are presented as Log Removal Value (LRV) compared 127 to the untreated sample. The assay was performed in triplicate, and average values with standard errors are 128 shown. (C) Cytotoxicity of HTCCs with DS ranging from 57% to 77% in vitro at 100 μg/ml. Cell viability was assessed 129 with XTT assay. Data on the y-axis represent the percentage of values obtained for the untreated reference

Vero (MERS-CoV) or Vero E6 cells 138 (SARS-CoV-2) were inoculated with a given virus in the presence of different concentrations of HTCC. Replication 139 of viruses was evaluated at 48 h post-inoculation using RT-qPCR. The data are presented as Log Removal Value 140 (LRV) compared to the untreated sample. The assay was performed in triplicate, and average values with standard 141 errors are displayed.

FIGREF11.text: 156interaction. To verify whether the natural microenvironment, which is rich in sugars and 157 charged molecules, does not abrogate the effectiveness of the inhibitors, we employed HAE158 cultures that mirror the fully differentiated layer linng the conductive airways, as well as the 159 site of coronavirus replication. Briefly, fully differentiated HAE cultures were infected with a 160 given virus 26 in the presence of previously selected HTCCs (200 μg/ml) or control PBS. 161 Following inoculation, apical lavage samples were collected daily, and replication kinetics for 162 each virus was investigated. The analysis revealed that the polymer efficiently hampered 163 SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV also in this model. For MERS-CoV, the inhibitory effect was 164 the most evident at 72 h p.i., while for SARS-CoV-2 the most substantial decline of virus 165progeny was observed at 24 h p.i.(Figure 3). Whether such kinetics will be reflected in vivo it 166 is to be investigated.

FIGREF13.text: Ex vivo inhibition of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 by HTCC in human airway epithelium cultures. HAE 174 cultures were exposed to MERS-CoV or SARS-CoV-2 in the presence of HTCC-63 (for MERS-CoV) or HTCC-77 (for 175 SARS-CoV-2) at 200 μg/ml or control PBS. To analyze virus replication kinetics, each day post infection, 100 μl of 176 1 × PBS was applied to the apical surface of HAE cultures and collected after 10 min of incubation at 37°C.

FIGREF15.text: 183replication results from the electrostatic interaction between the polymer and the Spike protein184 of coronaviruses. We hypothesize that the selectivity of the inhibitors yields from the fitting 185 charge distributions on the polymer and on the S proteins on the viral surface. While the 186 interaction of a single charged moiety is relatively weak, the concatemeric nature of the virus 187 and the polymer stabilizes the binding. Such structure-based interaction may be an interesting 188 entry point for further fine-tuning of the polymeric inhibitors of viral replication. 189 To ensure that the observed effect was a result of coronavirus entry inhibition by HTCC, 190 two experiments were performed. First, HAE cultures were inoculated with MERS-CoV in the 191 presence of HTCC-63 (200 μg/ml) or control PBS and incubated for 2 h at 37°C. Next, cells 192 were fixed, immunostained for MERS-CoV N protein and actin. Virus entry was analyzed with 193 confocal microscopy. To visualize the effect, the signal attributed to intracellular MERS-Coronavirus internalization into susceptible cells is hampered by HTCC. (A) Pre-cooled HAE cultures 199 were incubated with ice-cold MERS-CoV suspension in the presence or absence of HTCC-63 (200 μg/ml) for 2 h 200 at 37°C. Next, cells were fixed in PFA and immunostained for MERS-CoV N protein and actin. Virus entry was 201 analyzed with confocal microscopy. The data shown are representative of three independent experiments, each 202 performed in triplicate. * P < 0.05. (B) A549 cells overexpressing ACE2 were incubated with lentiviral particles 203 bearing GFP reporter gene, pseudotyped with SARS-CoV-2 Spike (S-SARS-CoV-2), VSV control G protein (VSV-G) 204 or particles without an envelope protein (ΔEnv) in the presence of HTCC-77 or control PBS. After 2 h at 37°C cells 205 were washed with PBS and overlaid with fresh medium. Following 72 h incubation, GFP signal was measured 206 using fluorometer and pseudovirus entry is presented as Relative Fluorescence Units per ml. The assay was 207 performed in triplicate, and average values with standard errors are presented. ** P < 0.005. 208 209 Due to the limited availability of tools for the SARS-CoV-2 we were not able to replicate 210 the experiment for this virus. Here, we employed a surrogate system based on lentiviral vectors 211 pseudotyped with full-length Spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. A549 cells overexpressing the 212 ACE2 protein were incubated with pseudovirions harboring SARS-CoV-2 Spike or control 213 VSV-G protein in the presence of HTCC-77 (100 μg/ml) or control PBS for 2 h at 37°C. After 214 72 h p.i. cells were lysed, and pseudovirus entry was quantified by measurement of the reporter 215 GFP protein. The analysis showed a significant reduction in SARS-CoV-2 Spike pseudoviruses 216 internalization in the presence of the polymer, while no inhibition was observed for the control 217 VSV-G (Figure 4B). 218 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF16.text: 221 co-localization with its entry receptor, DPP4 in the presence or absence of the HTCC. For this, 222 human cell line Huh7 was inoculated with the virus or mock in the presence of HTCC-63 223 (100 μg/ml) or control PBS and incubated for 2 h at 4°C. Subsequently, cells were fixed and 224 immunostained for the DPP4 and MERS-CoV N using specific antibodies. Virus co-225 localization with its receptor was examined using confocal microscopy. Obtained results 226 demonstrated that in the control samples, virions co-localize with the DPP4 protein, while in 227 the presence of the polymer, this interaction is blocked (HTCC blocks interaction between the virus and its entry receptor. Pre-cooled Huh7 cells were 231 incubated for 3 h at 4°C with ice-cold MERS-CoV or mock in the presence or absence of HTCC-63 (100 μg/ml).

FIGREF17.text: were fixed with PFA and immunostained for MERS-CoV-N (green), DPP4 (red) and nuclear DNA (blue). 233 MERS-CoV interaction with the DPP4 protein was analyzed with confocal microscopy. Co-localisation of DPP4 234 with MERS-CoV-N was determined by confocal microscopy and is presented as Manders' M2 coefficient. The 235 decrease in colocalization was statistically significant (P < 0.0005). Each image represents maximum projection 236 of axial planes. Representative images are shown. 237 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF18.text: One may speculate that the inhibition results from the concatemeric nature of the virus surface243    and the fact that the polymer with appropriate charge distribution can interact with multiple 244 sites on this surface. While the interaction of the monomer is relatively weak, and no inhibition 245 is observable for monomers, the sum of interactions stabilizes the binding and specific 246 inhibition is observed. Considering that the extended chain length for the HTCC used is 247 ~700 nm this scenario seems realistic 27 . If that would be true, HTCC would constitute a first 248 structure-specific inhibitor of viral replication. The major disadvantage of the HTCC is that, at 249 present, it is not registered for use in humans. However, previous experience with HTCC in 250 different laboratories shows that it may be delivered topically to the lungs, it is not associated 251 with toxicity, and it does not worsen the lung function 25 . We believe that HTCC is a promising 252 drug candidate that should be further studied, as it provides a ready-to-use solution for 253 SARS-CoV-2 and future emerging coronaviruses.

FIGREF20.text: Vero E6 (Cercopithecus aethiops; kidney epithelial; ATCC: CCL-81 and CRL-268 1586), Huh7 (Homo sapiens; hepatocellular carcinoma; ECACC: 01042712) and A549 cells 269 with ACE2 overexpression (A549/ACE2) 29 were cultured in Dulbecco's MEM (Thermo Fisher 270 Scientific, Poland) supplemented with 3% fetal bovine serum (heat-inactivated; Thermo Fisher 271 Scientific, Poland) and antibiotics: penicillin (100 U/ml), streptomycin (100 μg/ml), and 272 ciprofloxacin (5 μg/ml). Cells were maintained at 37°C under 5% CO2. 273 274 Human airway epithelium (HAE) cultures 275 Human airway epithelial cells were isolated from conductive airways resected from 276 transplant patients. The study was approved by the Bioethical Committee of the Medical 277 University of Silesia in Katowice, Poland (approval no: KNW/0022/KB1/17/10 dated 278 16.02.2010). Written consent was obtained from all patients. Cells were dislodged by protease 279 treatment, and later mechanically detached from the connective tissue. Further, cells were 280 trypsinized and transferred onto permeable Transwell insert supports ( = 6.5 mm). Cell 281 differentiation was stimulated by the media additives and removal of media from the apical side 282 after the cells reached confluence. Cells were cultured for 4-6 weeks to form well-differentiated, 283 pseudostratified mucociliary epithelium. All experiments were performed in accordance with 284 relevant guidelines and regulations.

Following 2 h incubation at 37°C, unbound virions were removed by washing 319 with 200 μl of 1 × PBS and HAE cultures were maintained at an air-liquid interphase for the 320 rest of the experiment. To analyze virus replication kinetics, each day p.i., 100 μl of 1 × PBS 321 was applied at the apical surface of HAE and collected following the 10 min incubation at 32°C. 322 All samples were stored at −80°C and analyzed using RT-qPCR.323 324 Isolation of nucleic acids and reverse transcription (RT) 325 Viral DNA/RNA Kit (A&A Biotechnology, Poland) was used for nucleic acid isolation 326 from cell culture supernatants, according to the manufacturer's instructions. cDNA samples 327 were prepared with a High Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit (Thermo Fisher 328 Scientific, Poland), according to the manufacturer's instructions.

FIGREF26.text: were seeded on 10 cm 2 dishes, cultured for 24 h at 37°C with 5% CO2 and363 transfected using polyethyleneimine (Sigma-Aldrich, Poland) with the lentiviral packaging 364 plasmid (psPAX), the VSV-G envelope plasmid (pMD2G) or SARS-CoV-2 S glycoprotein 365 (pCAGGS-SARS-CoV-2-S) and third plasmid encoding GFP protein (Lego-G2). Cells were 366 further cultured for 72 h at 37°C with 5% CO2 and pseudoviruses were collected every 24 h and 367 stored at 4°C. 368 A549/ACE2 cells were seeded in 48-wells plates, cultured for 24 h at 37°C with 5% 369 CO2 and transduced with pseudoviruses harboring VSV-G or S-SARS-CoV-2 proteins or 370 lacking the fusion protein (ΔEnv) in the presence of polybrene (4 µg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich, 371 Poland) and HTCC-77 (100 μg/ml) or control PBS . After 4 h incubation at 37°C unbound 372 virions were removed by washing thrice with 1 × PBS and cells were further cultured for 72 h 373 at 37°C with 5% CO2. Cells were lysed in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris, 150 mM NaCl, 374 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 0.1% SDS, pH 7.5) and transferred onto black 375 96-wells plates. Fluorescence levels were measured on a microplate reader Gemini EM 376 (Molecular Devices, UK).

TABREF0.text: Primers and probes.The reaction was carried out according to the scheme: 2 min at 50°C and 10 min at 92°C, followed by 40 cycles of 15 s at 92°C and 1 min at 60°C. In order to assess the copy number for N gene, DNA standards were prepared, as described before 26 .Fixed cells were permeabilized with 0.1% Triton X-100 in 1 × PBS and incubated overnight at 4°C in 1× PBS supplemented with 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 0.5% Tween 20. To visualize MERS-CoV particles, cells were incubated for 2 h at room temperature with mouse anti-MERS-CoV N IgGs (1:000 dilution, Sino Biological, China), followed by 1 h of incubation with Alexa Fluor 488-labeled goat anti-mouse IgG (2.5 µg/ml; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Poland). Actin filaments was stained using phalloidin coupled with Alexa Fluor 633 349 (0.2 U/ml; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Poland). Nuclear DNA was stained with DAPI (4',6'diamidino-2-phenylindole) (0.1 µg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich, Poland). Immunostained cultures were mounted on glass slides in ProLong Gold antifade medium (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Poland). Fluorescent images were acquired under a Leica TCS SP5 II confocal microscope (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Mannheim, Germany) and a Zeiss LSM 710 confocal microscope (Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH). Images were acquired using Leica Application Suite Advanced Fluorescence LAS AF v. 2.2.1 (Leica Microsystems CMS GmbH) or ZEN 2012 SP1 software (Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH) deconvolved with Huygens Essential package version 4.4
